description: A catastrophic famine that killed about a fifth of the Estonian and Livonian population (70,000–75,000 people) over two years due to severe climate conditions and poor policy decisions.

climate_conditions.general: Part of the Little Ice Age with cold springs and summers, average temperatures were 1.5 °C lower during the 1690s.

specific.summer_1695: Cold and rainy, followed by early autumn frost.
specific.1696: Continued cold conditions with summer rains.

agricultural.1692-1694: Poor harvests due to shorter summers and longer winters.
agricultural.summer_1695: Excessive rain destroyed crops and hay.
agricultural.summer_1696: Heavy rains wrecked harvests, yielding as little as three percent in some areas.

societal.by_end_of_summer_1696: Many peasants, farmhands, and even nobility were destitute and hungry.
societal.autumn_1696: Famine took hold, death rates began to rise.
societal.winter_1696-97: Corpses remained unburied until spring due to severe winter.

regional_impact.salt_shortage: Impacted by colder climate and excessive rain in Portugal, leading to preservation issues for meat and fish.
regional_impact.grain_export: Large quantities of grain were shipped to Sweden and Finland despite local famine.

aftermath.great_northern_war: Peter the Great cited inadequate provisioning during the famine as a pretext for declaring war against Sweden in 1700.

references.title: Great Historical Events That Were Significantly Affected by the Weather: 4, The Great Famines in Finland and Estonia
references.source: Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society
